result.execSummary:
The defendant Ian A Marten was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Misappropriate ID Info - Obtain Money [Modifiers: Repeater], a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.201(2)(a).
  • Possession of Narcotic Drugs [Modifiers: Repeater], a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(3g)(am).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
Defendant IS eligible for the Challenge Incarceration Program and the Substance Abuse Program.  Sentence Credit of 52 days were granted.
Concurrent with: Count 5 and any other sentence.

superMiscConds.notes: Restitution to be paid in a the amount of $1,939.97 to Associated Bank during incarceration as a condition of extended supervision.
Costs to be paid as a condition of extended supervision.
Follow through with any treatment, counseling recommended by Agent.  No use or possession of illegal drugs/drug paraphernalia. Comply with random urine screens.  Maintain absolute sobriety.

Defendant to avoid any person or place associated with the sale, distribution or use of illegal controlled substances.
  Court ordered financial obligations and restitution payable out of 25% of inmate's funds while incarcerated.
  If Probation/Extended Supervision is revoked and/or a prison term ordered, outstanding financial obligations shall be collected pursuant to statutory provisions, including deductions from inmate prison monies.  If discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  Collections may include income assignment.

dated 12/12/16 from the parents of Ian Marten regarding request for early release
  **Reviewed by Judge Ramirez on 12/19/16-No response by the court, authors of the letter are not parties to the case.**
Transcript received and filed for the following date and event: Plea and Sentencing Hearing, October 16, 2015 filed by Erin P. Furgason, RPR
with Elements of criminal offenses to which plea is being entered.

Defendant Ian A Marten in court, in custody, with attorney Jorge R Fragoso.   Lesli S Boese appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant pleads guilty to counts 3 and 5.  Court finds the defendant guilty of counts 3 and 5.  Counts 1,2,4,6 and 7 are dismissed and read in.  State gives recommendations.  Attorney Fragoso makes statements.  Defendant makes statements.  Victim makes statements, requests contact with the defendant.

The Court Orders the Following:  Count #3   
Imposed Sentence of:
4 years Imprisonment (Credit - 52 days ) concurrent to count #5. Concurrent to any other sentence.
2 years of Initial Confinement
2 years of Extended Supervision

Conditions of Extended Supervision:
Absolute Sobriety; Random U.A.s;
No Use or Possession of illegal drugs or drug paraphernalia;
Follow through with any treatment and/or counseling recommended by Agent;
Defendant to avoid any person or place associated with the sale, distribution, or use of illegal controlled substances;
Restitution: $1,939.97 to be paid to Associated Bank during incarceration and as a condition of extended supervision;
Cost: $278.00 to be paid during incarceration and as a condition of extended supervision;   
Court ordered financial obligations and restitution payable out of 25% of inmate's funds while incarcerated;
DNA Sample previously done, not ordered
Defendant is eligible for the Challenge Incarceration Program
Defendant is eligible for the Substance Abuse Program
Felony warnings, immigration warnings,  voting rights and firearms warnings given.  

The Court Orders the Following:  Count # 5
Imposed Sentence of:
3 years 6 months Imprisonment (Credit - 52 days ) concurrent to count #3.  Concurrent to any other sentence
18 months of Initial Confinement
2 years of Extended Supervision

Conditions of Extended Supervision:
Absolute Sobriety; Random U.A.s;
No Use or Possession of illegal drugs or drug paraphernalia;
Follow through with any treatment and/or counseling recommended by Agent;
Defendant to avoid any person or place associated with the sale, distribution, or use of illegal controlled substances
Cost: $268.00 to be paid during incarceration and as a condition of extended supervision   
Court ordered financial obligations and restitution payable out of 25% of inmate's funds while incarcerated.
DNA Sample previously done, not ordered
Defendant is eligible for the Challenge Incarceration Program
Defendant is eligible for the Substance Abuse Program
Felony warnings, immigration warnings,  voting rights and firearms warnings given.

Court grants request.  Court orders the defendant remain in the Waukesha County Jail until the next hearing.  Plea/sentencing hearing scheduled for October 16, 2015 at 09:30 am.
